Award.AwardTitle: Encouraging Interdisciplinary Learning in Science, Math, and Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is increasing the number of students graduating in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields and better preparing these graduates for their careers or graduate school. The objectives of the project are to:

(1) Increase the number of well-educated and skilled employees in technical areas of national need by encouraging exploration of graduate level study and/or improving professional development and job seeking skills. Activities include career counseling, internships, conferences, graduate school fairs, and research opportunities. Workshops are being provided that address topics such as exploring scholarships and fellowships, applying to graduate school, and preparing for the GRE. As a result of these activities, 92% of S-STEM program graduates enroll in graduate school or find employment within their field.

(2) Improve educational opportunities for students pursuing a baccalaureate degree in science, technology, or mathematics, with a special emphasis on talented but financially-disadvantaged students. The program is designed to support 20 participants during each year of the four-year project period. Program applicants are required to have a GPA of 3.0 or greater and must be formally accepted into one of the following programs: Computer Science, Mathematics, Chemistry, Biology, or Biochemistry.

(3) Maintain 100% retention rates and degree attainment among S-STEM program participants. Activities related to this objective include faculty mentoring, tutoring, and cohort gatherings.

(4) Strengthen the partnership between the college and employers and between the college and regional graduate schools and professional organizations in the fields of science, technology, and mathematics. By coordinating with local businesses and professional organizations, students can explore STEM-related career opportunities. Students are also provided opportunities to explore graduate schools of interest.

(5) Maintain strong student support programs at the college and integrate the S-STEM objectives with pre-existing student support programs. As a result, 100% of S-STEM program participants obtain a baccalaureate degree in a STEM field.

Intellectual Merit: This project advances knowledge and understanding in the STEM fields by diversifying the pool of young graduates and ensuring that they are well prepared for the next step in their careers. The qualifications of the leadership team are reflected in the 100% retention rate of CSEMS/S-STEM participants during the past nine years. The combination of activities and services represents a unique and comprehensive program that is necessary to meet the needs of the target population. The project is designed to encourage active learning, and participants have access to a wide range of laboratory equipment, services, technology, and faculty support.

Broader Impacts: The college has a long history of providing educational opportunities for underserved populations. The S-STEM project fits into efforts at the college to increase undergraduate student research and internship opportunities and services the needs of the high technology workplace with well-prepared, but traditionally underserved, young adults.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past four years, the NSF S-STEM scholarship program at The College of St. Scholastica (CSS) has worked to increase the number of students graduating in STEM fields, and to better prepare these graduates for STEM careers or graduate school. The program focused on students who are talented but financially disadvantaged, with an emphasis on women and students underrepresented in STEM fields. Overall, the program supported 54 students majoring in biochemistry, chemistry, biology, mathematics, and computer sciences. Of the 54, 27 scholars (50%) were women, and 6 scholars (11%) were people of color.  Students were required to maintain a 3.0 cumulative GPA; an “intrusive advising” approach was initiated to support students who were struggling academically. Over the four-year grant period, our scholars achieved an average cumulative GPA of 3.62.

Each student received a scholarship award of up to $6,500 per year and had the opportunity to participate in activities that provided support and exposed scholars to the many STEM research and career opportunities available. Offerings included seminars, annual fall and spring banquets, visits to the Nobel Conference at Gustavus Adolphus College, and participation in the Northern Michigan University Programming Competition. Students utilized helpful resources such as GRE preparation courses, mock interviews, and job fairs; visits were also made to Environmental Protection Agency research laboratories in Duluth, MN, and to Boston Scientific facilities in Maple Grove, MN. Additionally, many students participated in internships with organizations such as Twin Ports Testing, the City of Duluth, and Digi-key Electronics. As one scholar noted, “The S-STEM program encouraged me to attend scientific talks and conferences to broaden my understanding of a higher education in the sciences and a future career in research.”

A significant highlight of our program was the large number of students that participated in research experiences. Overall, 33 students (61%) participated in research—examples include a molecular biology summer research experience at the University of Kansas, chemistry education research at Loyola University Chicago, and chemical engineering research at the University of Wisconsin Madison. These experiences gave students the chance to get a taste of STEM graduate school. They worked in labs consisting of undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and professors, and they were able to use state-of-the-art equipment to perform original work. Research momentum continues to grow on the CSS campus, exemplified by the recent creation of a summer research program and the initiation of Clare Boothe Luce grant support to encourage female undergraduate participation in STEM research. Additionally, scholars and program faculty were able to share research findings and network with other STEM professionals at national conferences (including meetings of the National Council on Undergraduate Research, the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, the American Chemical Society, and the Association of College and University Biology Educators).

These varied activities and experiences have contributed to strong STEM academic and career aspirations among a number of program participants. Graduates have entered into a variety of STEM careers; job titles include programmer analyst, lab manager, and math teacher, among others. Several other graduates have gone on to pursue further STEM education and are enrolled in Ph.D. programs in fields including biochemistry, organic chemistry, and nuclear chemistry at places like The Ohio State University, the University of Michigan, Michigan State University, Iowa State University, and the Mayo Graduate School. Scholars still in the program have similar future plans, including working as a software developer and ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Over the past four years, the NSF S-STEM scholarship program at The College of St. Scholastica (CSS) has worked to increase the number of students graduating in STEM fields, and to better prepare these graduates for STEM careers or graduate school. The program focused on students who are talented but financially disadvantaged, with an emphasis on women and students underrepresented in STEM fields. Overall, the program supported 54 students majoring in biochemistry, chemistry, biology, mathematics, and computer sciences. Of the 54, 27 scholars (50%) were women, and 6 scholars (11%) were people of color. Students were required to maintain a 3.0 cumulative GPA; an "intrusive advising" approach was initiated to support students who were struggling academically. Over the four-year grant period, our scholars achieved an average cumulative GPA of 3.62. Each student received a scholarship award of up to $6,500 per year and had the opportunity to participate in activities that provided support and exposed scholars to the many STEM research and career opportunities available. Offerings included seminars, annual fall and spring banquets, visits to the Nobel Conference at Gustavus Adolphus College, and participation in the Northern Michigan University Programming Competition. Students utilized helpful resources such as GRE preparation courses, mock interviews, and job fairs; visits were also made to Environmental Protection Agency research laboratories in Duluth, MN, and to Boston Scientific facilities in Maple Grove, MN. Additionally, many students participated in internships with organizations such as Twin Ports Testing, the City of Duluth, and Digi-key Electronics. As one scholar noted, "The S-STEM program encouraged me to attend scientific talks and conferences to broaden my understanding of a higher education in the sciences and a future career in research." A significant highlight of our program was the large number of students that participated in research experiences. Overall, 33 students (61%) participated in research—examples include a molecular biology summer research experience at the University of Kansas, chemistry education research at Loyola University Chicago, and chemical engineering research at the University of Wisconsin Madison. These experiences gave students the chance to get a taste of STEM graduate school. They worked in labs consisting of undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and professors, and they were able to use state-of-the-art equipment to perform original work. Research momentum continues to grow on the CSS campus, exemplified by the recent creation of a summer research program and the initiation of Clare Boothe Luce grant support to encourage female undergraduate participation in STEM research. Additionally, scholars and program faculty were able to share research findings and network with other STEM professionals at national conferences (including meetings of the National Council on Undergraduate Research, the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, the American Chemical Society, and the Association of College and University Biology Educators). These varied activities and experiences have contributed to strong STEM academic and career aspirations among a number of program participants. Graduates have entered into a variety of STEM careers; job titles include programmer analyst, lab manager, and math teacher, among others. Several other graduates have gone on to pursue further STEM education and are enrolled in Ph.D. programs in fields including biochemistry, organic chemistry, and nuclear chemistry at places like The Ohio State University, the University of Michigan, Michigan State University, Iowa State University, and the Mayo Graduate School. Scholars still in the program have similar future plans, including working as a software developer and attending graduate school for information security.
